Situation1: The partner seems mildly stressed after a routine workday.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: I glanced at the clock above the register, counting down the minutes until my shift ended. My partner stood just outside the store, waiting for me, her shoulders slightly hunched, eyes tired. I could tell she’d had a rough day, and I wanted nothing more than to be there for her, to listen and reassure her that everything would be okay. But right now, I was the only cashier on duty, and the end-of-day rush had begun. Customers lined up, some with large purchases, and I had to focus—every bill, every receipt, every number had to be perfect. One mistake could mean hours of paperwork or worse, a loss I’d have to explain to my manager. My mind tugged in two directions: the urge to hurry so I could comfort her, and the pressure to slow down, double-check every transaction. My heart ached as I watched her wait, knowing she needed me, while my hands moved mechanically over the register, trapped by the demands of my job.
